channel.title: Ramah: Good News Feed
channel.description: Positive news stories from around the world, filtered by sentiment analysis

item.title: Winter Olympics 2026: GB men win curling semi-final, figure skating and more – live
item.description: GB progress to men’s curling final, USA beat Canada in overtime to win gold in women’s ice hockey, USA’s Alysa Liu triumphs in figure skating.

item.title: Hull KR on top of the world after resisting thrilling Brisbane fightback
item.description: Hull KR are champions of the rugby league world for the first time in their history, after holding off a late rally from the NRL premiers Brisbane Broncos to win a first World Club Challenge.

item.title: Manchester United v Atlético Madrid: Women’s Champions League playoff – live
item.description: 55 min: Possession is flying back and forth with the game hitting a bit of a lull but still fairly well paced.

item.title: Nottingham Forest dominate Fenerbahce to give Vítor Pereira perfect start
item.description: Evangelos Marinakis’s grand aim at the outset of this season, before moving on to his fourth manager since August, was to win this competition across the Bosphorus in Besiktas in May and, for all of the chaos and valid criticism, on this evidence it is very much an achievable aim.

item.title: Baby chicks link certain sounds with shapes, just like humans do
item.description: When people are shown a spiky shape next to a rounded one and asked which shape is called "kiki" and which one is "bouba," people from all kinds of cultures overwhelmingly associate "bouba" with the blob-like shape and "kiki" with the more jagged, pointy one.

item.title: Schools in England to get budget for children with special needs as part of Send overhaul
item.description: Children in England with special needs will receive individual support and therapy directly from their schools as part of the government’s overhaul of England’s special education provision.

item.title: In a thrilling comeback win, U.S. women take home Olympic hockey gold over Canada
item.description: MILAN — With Olympic gold on the line, with just over two minutes to play in regulation of Thursday's final match, it was the U.S.

item.title: 'Dude, good luck': the Olympic wit and wisdom of a pioneering African skeleton racer
item.description: Skeleton was actually the third sport Frimpong took up to chase his dream of becoming an Olympian.

item.title: Johann Ludwig Bach: The Leipzig Cantatas album review – this distant cousin’s music is a remarkable discovery
item.description: We’ll probably never know why Johann Sebastian Bach broke off his prodigious flow of sacred cantatas in 1726 to instead perform a set of 18 by a distant third cousin, but as this revelatory four-disc set demonstrates, we should be glad he did.

item.title: ‘It feels like a worse version of Lotto’: Guardian Australia readers on the great intergenerational wealth transfer
item.description: Over the next two decades, economists predict that $5.4tn will be passed down from ageing baby boomers to their beneficiaries.

item.title: Dance with Tom: an irresistibly joyous show for bubs who like to bop
item.description: There’s an unending list of things to be worried about as a new parent: nap time, tummy time, vaccinations, viral illnesses.

item.title: Rose-tinted glasses: why I’m gunning for an Australian upset in the best actress Oscar race | Rebecca Shaw
item.description: Every year around this time, I become like a cliche TV husband who disappears from his wife and children’s lives in order to follow footy season.

item.title: ‘A love letter to Beirut’: Lana Daher on sifting 20,000 sources and 70 years of film to make Do You Love Me
item.description: At one point in Lana Daher’s film Do You Love Me, a woman questions the repeated advice of those around her to simply forget Lebanon’s 15-year civil war that ended in 1990.

item.title: Rare gifted word-learner dogs like to share their toys
item.description: We love hearing about the latest findings coming out of an Eötvös Loránd University (ELU) research group focused on gifted word learner (GWL) dogs—if only for the pictures of adorable doggoes playing with their toys.

item.title: Pigs, punchups and a foaming red carpet: 10 amazing Baftas moments – ranked
item.description: Typically, the Baftas have fewer memorable moments than, say, the Oscars.

item.title: Alysa Liu carries US medal hopes into concluding women’s free skate at the Milan Cortina Olympics
item.description: MILAN (AP) — Alysa Liu is left to bear the ambitions of the American figure skating team on Thursday night, when the last of the “Blade Angels” with a legitimate shot at the Olympic gold medal tries to catch Japanese teammates Ami Nakai and Kaori Sakamoto during the women’s free skate at the Milan Cortina Games.

item.title: Healthy life expectancy falls across Scotland
item.description: People in Scotland are spending a greater proportion of their life in poor health than in previous years, new figures from the National Records of Scotland (NRS) show.

item.title: ‘There has to be glitter’: can the Rio carnival give up its love of beach-polluting microplastics?
item.description: Whether it is embellishing elaborate costumes, delicately applied as eye makeup, or smeared across bare skin, glitter is everywhere at Rio de Janeiro’s carnival in Brazil.

item.title: Special needs support eligibility to be reviewed at start of secondary school in England
item.description: Children with a legal right to special needs support will face a review when they move to secondary school, with the first cohort to be impacted currently in key stage 1, the Guardian understands.

item.title: Man on the Run review – archival delve into Paul McCartney’s post-Beatles era is a welcome revisit
item.description: Another hefty legacy project for Paul McCartney, who acts as off-camera interviewee and executive producer in this documentary by Morgan Neville.

item.title: British Gas owner pauses share buyback as profits plummet
item.description: The owner of British Gas has paused its plan to buy back shares from shareholders after the company’s full-year profits slumped by almost 39%.

item.title: You be the judge: should my best friend stop wearing the same perfume as me?
item.description: Marta wants her scent to be unique, but Elsa thinks copying her friend is just sharing the joy.

item.title: TV set is most popular way to watch YouTube in UK, study finds
item.description: The television has replaced laptops, tablets and smartphones as the most common device for UK viewers to watch YouTube at home, according to data confirming the platform’s place as a living room mainstay.

item.title: Say goodbye to the sex drought! What the Danes can teach us about making more love
item.description: While other countries are deep in a sex recession, the Danish drive shows no signs of stalling.

item.title: US funding for global internet freedom ‘effectively gutted’
item.description: For nearly two decades, the US quietly funded a global effort to keep the internet from splintering into fiefdoms run by authoritarian governments.

item.title: White House says Iran would be 'wise' to make deal, as US ramps up military presence
item.description: The White House has warned Iran would be "very wise" to make a deal with the US, amid reports that President Donald Trump is weighing fresh military action against the Islamic Republic.

item.title: In her memoir, Gisèle Pelicot reveals the love she kept secret
item.description: For years, the story of Gisèle Pelicot has been defined by horror — the woman at the centre of France's most infamous mass rape trial, who chose to waive anonymity and became a global icon in the fight against sexual violence.

item.title: KPMG asks Sydney writers’ festival to delete its name from website after Randa Abdel-Fattah confirmed as speaker
item.description: Global accounting giant KPMG has distanced itself from the Sydney writers’ festival, requesting its name be removed from the event’s website where it was listed as a corporate partner.

item.description: Reform UK would restore the two-child benefit cap in full, Robert Jenrick has announced, in a major U-turn for the party that critics said would plunge hundreds of thousands of children into poverty.

item.title: Federal MPs accept free sport tickets from gambling companies amid calls to restrict wagering ads
item.description: At least six federal Labor and Liberal politicians, including an assistant minister and shadow ministers, have disclosed they accepted free tickets to lucrative sporting events from major gambling companies in the past six months, as the government faces calls to restrict wagering ads and better regulate the sector.

item.title: ‘Let’s go out in a beautiful fashion’: Australian theatre company says goodbye with one last wondrous show

item.title: US star Mikaela Shiffrin wins slalom to break 8-year Olympic drought
item.description: CORTINA D’AMPEZZO, Italy (AP) — Mikaela Shiffrin’s turbulent, 12-year Olympic journey came full circle Wednesday when she won the slalom by a massive 1.50 seconds to break her long medal drought at the Winter Games.

item.title: Sweet redemption for Mikaela Shiffrin, who wins Olympic gold
item.description: CORTINA D'AMPEZZO, Italy — In her final race of the 2026 Winter Games, skiing in the slalom, widely considered her best event, Alpine legend Mikaela Shiffrin finally did it, winning a gold medal on a shimmering cold, blue-sky day in the mountains above Cortina.

item.title: Household energy bills in Great Britain forecast to fall by £117 a year
